thread.title: Weatherman Liam Dutton nails pronunciation of tongue-twister town, Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch | DailyTelegraph
thread.title_full: Weatherman Liam Dutton nails pronunciation of tongue-twister town, Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch | DailyTelegraph

author: Network Writers
title: Weatherman Liam Dutton nails pronunciation of tongue-twister town, Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch | DailyTelegraph
text:
IT IS hard not to feel sorry for UK weather presenter Liam Dutton who was forced to pronounce the UK’s longest-named town, Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch, during his weather report. But there is no need because he nailed it.
This week’s Indian summer weather was particularly felt in the small northwest Wales village, which, um, reached a kinda-warm high of 21C.
Best weatherman ever? It left Dutton with little choice but to mention the location in his Channel 4 weather report.
Other Stories Shot by police to prevent rampage News 0 comments Sales’ cutting question for PM Television How Hayne left Aussie businessman devastated More Sports 0 comments How Duran Duran got their groove back Entertainment 0 comments Why being an escort has made me a better mother Rendezview 0 comments ‘Safety is my middle name’ Nsw 0 comments Dutton didn’t miss a beat though, pronouncing the town’s 58-letter name like a pro.
Clearly his 10 years reading the weather has helped, not to mention that he learnt to speak Welsh as a kid.
While the segment was prerecorded it is understood that Dutton nailed the pronunciation on his first attempt.
I'm about to say Llanfair­pwllgwyngyll­gogery­chwyrn­drobwll­llan­tysilio­gogo­goch on the TV - @Channel4 at 7.55pm. pic.twitter.com/ReE73lN6Ul
— Liam Dutton (@liamdutton) September 8, 2015 Thanks for the kind words this evening, all! ;-) #Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch
— Liam Dutton (@liamdutton) September 8, 2015 He is not the only person who has pulled off the impressive feat.
Actress Naomi Watts, whose grandfather was born in Wales where she lived for a period, impressed Jimmy Kimmel earlier this year with her ability to pronounce Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch.
Naomi Watts impressed Jimmy Kimmel Believe it or not but Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch is not the longest-named place in the world - that honour goes to a hill in New Zealand called Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateapokaiwhenuakitanatahu.
Like a boss. http://t.co/yK9a3XCAeL
— Clarke (@CrossfitClarke) September 9, 2015 Give @liamdutton an Emmy, a Grammy, an Oscar a Nobel and his own tv show! #llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch
— NicSilvano (@Nicsilvano) September 9, 2015 Surely @liamdutton did that for a bet? #C4News #Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch
— Jon Reed (@jonreed) September 8, 2015 Originally published as Weatherman nails tongue-twister town
